On Tuesday, April 29, 2003, at 10:47 PM, Curt Sampson wrote:

> On Mon, 28 Apr 2003 twall@... wrote:
>
>> In short, because ANT doesn't have built-in, precompiled and 
>> configured
>> dependency rules and flags for things like "cc", "ld", and so on.
>
> Nor does make. All of that is in a couple of hundred lines of code
> /usr/share/mk/sys.mk, at least on Berkely-flavoured Unix systems.

My point was that in order for ant to be useful for those things it 
would need to provide the predefined tasks.  If you have to write up 
the task from scratch (especially if you have to write java code for 
it), it's easier to script it than to code it.

>
>> These are things that are trivially constructed in a shell call or
>> make dependency rules, but rather complex, verbose, and circuitous
>> when wrapped in XML.
>
> Actually, make code is a pretty bad nightmare for any sort of complex
> build system as well. Just take a look at the almost four thousand 
> lines
> of make code in the various files in /usr/share/mk on a Berkely system
> (this is the support for building the entire OS) for a look. But yeah, 
> I
> agree that ant is not any better, at least at the moment.


Any large and complex system with today's tools looks pretty crappy.  
No matter how well laid out your build.xml or makefiles, you're still 
left traipsing through the stuff with a text editor (and no, an XML 
editor does not buy you anything related to comprehending the build 
structure).

Don't get me wrong.  I'd certainly like to see something that handles 
complexity weil, and allows for flexible and easy definition of 
dependencies, and a host of other things that a real build system 
should have.  It just doesn't look like ant is going there, probably 
because no one with the time to work on it sees a need.

The two major drawbacks I see currently with Ant for use in development 
are 1) requiring java code for customization, as it applies to doing 
things you'd typically do with a script for quick turnaround and 2) 
lack of a decent representation of conditional execution based on 
dependencies.

Both of these have a big effect on development time.
